depress.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to make someone feel very unhappy
depress.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The thought of taking the exam again depressed him.
It depresses me that nobody seems to care.
depress.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to prevent an economy from being as active and successful as it usually is
depress.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Several factors combined to depress the American economy.
depress.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to press something down, especially a part of a machine
depress.translation[0].definitions[2].no: In everyday English, people usually say they push (down) or press (down) a button rather than depress it:
Push this button for cold water.
depress.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to reduce the value of prices or wages
depress.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: High interest rates may depress share prices.
depress.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to prevent an economy, industry, market etc from working properly or being as active as it usually is
depress.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Several factors combined to depress the American economy.
Overproduction was blamed for depressing oil markets.
depress.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to reduce the value of something such as prices or wages
depress.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: Competition between workers will depress wage levels.
Profits have already been depressed by the recession.
